clinical_study.brief_title: Early Urinary Continence After Radical Prostatectomy: Surgical Procedure and Anatomic Landmarks
clinical_study.official_title: Complete Puborectalis, Puboperinealis Muscle and Urethral Rhabdomyosphincter Preservation in Laparoscopic Radical Prostatectomy: Anatomic Landmarks to Achieving Early Urinary Continence

brief_summary.textblock: This study describes how to perform a correct prostatic apex and membranous urethra in order to preserve all anatomical elements that are necessary to achieve a very fast urinary continence after open/laparoscopic/robotic radical prostatectomy, avoiding positive surgical margins at this level.

detailed_description.textblock: This study describes a simple technical variation, aimed at the sparing of the muscle systems and neurovascular bundles in order to achieve high rates of urinary continence in the early postoperative period ( the first two months after surgery) in prostate cancer patients undergoing radical prostatectomy.

primary_outcome.measure: change in the proportion of patients with of urinary incontinence
primary_outcome.time_frame: The follow-up was at 2 weeks, 4 weeks and 8 weeks after removal of the urethral catheter (one week after surgery), and, thereafter, once a month over the first year after surgery
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of the proportion of patients with urinary incontinence after laparoscopic radical prostatectomy

secondary_outcome.measure: change in the proportion of patients with recovery of the erectile function
secondary_outcome.time_frame: every month during the first year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: assessment of the recovery of the erectile function after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: number of patients with overall positive surgical margins
secondary_outcome.description: postoperative assessment of positive surgical margins

secondary_outcome.time_frame: until the completion of the study, with a mean follow-up of 72 months

study_pop.textblock: A series of 120 consecutive prostate cancer patients who underwent Laparoscopic Radical Prostatectomy from 2012 to 2018, always performed by the same surgeon

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age between 40 and 75 years
- A Body Mass Index lower than 35 Hg/m2
- Patients with organ-confined prostate cancer
- Signed informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindications for Laparoscopy
